title: Crohn's Disease with Obstructive Ileal Stricture
setup_script: A 28-year-old man with known Crohn's disease presents with crampy abdominal pain, nausea, and weight loss. CT enterography shows a 10 cm fibrostenotic stricture in the terminal ileum with proximal dilation and no abscess.

dynamic_flow.trigger: Assess disease history including previous flares, medications, and extraintestinal manifestations.
Perform physical exam focusing on abdominal tenderness, masses, and nutritional status.
Order labs (CBC, CRP, albumin), stool studies, and imaging to exclude abscess or fistula.
Discuss medical optimization: start corticosteroids or anti-TNF therapy if inflammatory component; evaluate nutrition.
Consider endoscopic balloon dilation for short, accessible strictures; discuss its limitations and recurrence.
Plan for surgical intervention due to long fibrostenotic segment causing obstruction; choose laparoscopic ileocecal resection.
Obtain informed consent; explain risk of short bowel syndrome, recurrence, and need for postoperative biologics.
Perform laparoscopic ileocecectomy with primary anastomosis; inspect abdomen for other disease segments.
Send resected specimen for pathology to confirm chronic inflammation and rule out malignancy.
Postoperative care: manage fluids, electrolytes, early feeding, and DVT prophylaxis; monitor for leak.
Reintroduce Crohn's medications postoperatively (immunomodulators or biologics) to prevent recurrence.
Educate patient on smoking cessation, nutrition, and the importance of regular follow-up and colon cancer screening.

critical_decision_points: Distinguishing inflammatory versus fibrostenotic Crohn's disease and optimizing medical therapy.
Deciding between endoscopic dilation and surgical resection for long strictures.
Performing laparoscopic ileocecectomy safely and preserving bowel length.
Postoperative management including early nutrition and prevention of recurrence.
Patient education on lifestyle modifications and adherence to surveillance.
